node.title: Can not compile custom object
node.bodyText:
Hello, after I wrote DarcyPressure object in step5 of tutorial 1, I met the problem that it could not be compiled. It shows that I can't find cstdlib, whereas I myself compiled the header file containing cstdlib separately using g++. I also had this problem with the offline version of MOOSE. It seems that I didn't install MOOSE correctly. Can anyone help me please? Thanks a lot.
The following is the information returned by the terminal

(moose) mestro@mestro-PC:~/projects/moose$ cd ..
(moose) mestro@mestro-PC:~/projects$ cd my_first/
(moose) mestro@mestro-PC:~/projects/my_first$ ls
a.out  build  doc  hs.c  include  lib  LICENSE  Makefile  my_first-opt  problems  README.md  run_tests  scripts  src  test  testroot  unit
(moose) mestro@mestro-PC:~/projects/my_first$ cd include/kernels/
(moose) mestro@mestro-PC:~/projects/my_first/include/kernels$ ls
DarcyPressure.h
(moose) mestro@mestro-PC:~/projects/my_first/include/kernels$ cd ../../src/kernels/
(moose) mestro@mestro-PC:~/projects/my_first/src/kernels$ ls
DarcyPressure.c
(moose) mestro@mestro-PC:~/projects/my_first/src/kernels$ cd ../../
(moose) mestro@mestro-PC:~/projects/my_first$ make -j 4
Using HIT from /home/mestro/projects/moose/framework/contrib/hit
Checking if header needs updating: /home/mestro/projects/moose/framework/include/base/MooseRevision.h...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/mestro/projects/moose/framework/build/unity_src/multiapps_Unity.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/mestro/projects/moose/framework/build/unity_src/interfacekernels_Unity.C...
......

Compiling C (in opt mode) /home/mestro/projects/my_first/src/kernels/DarcyPressure.c...
In file included from /home/mestro/anaconda3/envs/moose/libmesh/include/libmesh/threads.h:24,
                 from /home/mestro/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/HashMap.h:13,
                 from /home/mestro/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/MooseUtils.h:13,
                 from /home/mestro/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/InputParameters.h:13,
                 from /home/mestro/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/MooseObject.h:13,
                 from /home/mestro/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/ResidualObject.h:12,
                 from /home/mestro/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/KernelBase.h:12,
                 from /home/mestro/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/ADKernel.h:12,
                 from /home/mestro/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/ADKernelGrad.h:12,
                 from /home/mestro/projects/my_first/build/header_symlinks/DarcyPressure.h:2,
                 from /home/mestro/projects/my_first/src/kernels/DarcyPressure.c:1:
/home/mestro/anaconda3/envs/moose/libmesh/include/libmesh/libmesh_common.h:36:10: fatal error: cstdlib: No such file or directory
   36 | #include <cstdlib>
      |          ^~~~~~~~~
compilation terminated.
make: *** [/home/mestro/projects/moose/framework/build.mk:152：/home/mestro/projects/my_first/src/kernels/DarcyPressure.x86_64-conda-linux-gnu.opt.lo] 错误 1

Hello
The compiler thinks DarcyPressure is a C source file, because of the .c extension. Please rename it to .C (capital C) and let us know if that solves the issue.
Best,
Guillaume

node.title: Periodic BC for Discontinuous Galerkin
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE users,
We are implementing the DG kernels for advection, but for the moment, the periodic BC does not work.
An example input file is here https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/blob/main/test/tests/DGKernels/PosNegStraightEdge.i
In our view the DG kernel works only in the internal elements but for the variables on the boundaries the neighbor parts (e.g. _u_neighbor) do not work well.
Has anyone implemented Periodic BC for some Discontinuous Galerkin applications?
Any suggestion is very much appreciated.
Best Regards,
Daijun

We have noticed that periodic boundary conditions are activated only when the shape functions are FIRST LAGRANGE
but they do not work when the shape functions are CONSTANT MONOMIAL or FIRST MONOMIAL.
Does anybody know the reason for that?
And what could be a solution to make PBC working with CONSTANT MONOMIAL?
Thank you very much in advance for your suggestions.
Nicolò

Is CG having the strong continuity along the paired periodic boundaries? I am not sure if we can do that with DG. I think we should have something like a DG kernel to connect a paired sides. Do you get a run-time error for doing periodic boundary condition with DG? If not, the code at least should throw an error. Hope someone else can give you a better answer.

Hi Yaqi,
Thank you so much for your reply.
Currently we do not have an error for doing periodic boudary condition with DG kernels, it just do not work at boudary elements but the simulations can move on.
I think Nicolò's answer above points to a possible solution  for this, we want to check if there is PBC that can work with the shape function  CONSTANT MONOMIAL we are using for our simulation.
Thank you!
Best regards,
Daijun

Dear @YaqiWang
Yes, I believe CG (with first order Lagrange) with PBC removes the degrees of freedom of the variable along one of the paired surfaces, therefore there is continuity in the strong sense.
I am still not sure why this is not possible with constant monomial shape functions, it should be technically the same.
This does not depend specifically on the DGKernel, the same happens with CG,
but you never use constant monomial in that case.
Yes, as you point out, we should develop a kernel such that the variable at the neighboring element: _u_neighbor
can be fetched in the elements in the connected pair side.
Is there a function in moose that can provide the neighboring element in a periodic boundary?
The current DGKernel is not called for the boundary faces, therefore adding periodic BC has no effect,
the simulation can run though, but boundary condition remains zero flux.
Nicolò

Is there a function in moose that can provide the neighboring element in a periodic boundary?

libMesh probably has a function to allow us to find the periodic neighbor. But MOOSE probably does not have the support for properly evaluating coupled variables, material properties, etc. on the periodic neighbor. @lindsayad are these right?

Yes we have Elem::topological_neighbor for finding a periodic neighbor. @YaqiWang is right that all the plumbing in MOOSE is set up just to query and reinit finite element shape functions, variables, materials etc. for connected neighbors (neighbors accessible with elem->neighbor_ptr). It would take some changes to support periodic neighbors

node.title: Postprocessing: Total mass and total energy calculation porous flow module
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am solving a single-phase TH problem(porous_flow module)  where boundary conditions on a face are Dirichlet type for both pressure and temperature. How do I calculate the total mass and total energy for the given boundary?
Thank you,
Ranjeet

The simplest situation is when you're interested in the total flow into (or out of) the entire system.  Then you can use PorousFlowFluidMass or PorousFlowHeatEnergy.
Note that Dirichlet conditions are not recommended in PorousFlow since they frequently end up trying to withdraw fluid or heat from a region which contains none, so we try to encourage people to use one of the many PorousFlowSinks instead.
Nevertheless, Dirichlet BCs are really convenient.  So, use a PorousFlowOutflowBC to record your flux (study the save_in feature on that webpage).
@WilkAndy Thank you for the explanation. Calculated injected and produced mass using the Save-flux feature in these Boundary conditions.

node.title: StochasticTools: Trainers/skip_unconverged_samples Issue
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I'm having trouble using skip_unconverged_samples. I finally got past "must use / delimiter" and "reporter not declared" errors with converged_reporter, but I am now getting an error:

Reporter with the name "stoch_tools_converged/bool" within app "pr_sub093" was not found.

Which seems to stem from my chosen reporter. I'm using a PostProcessor that simply checks if the transient has run for 60+ seconds to determine that it has "converged":
[stoch_tools_converged]
    type = PostprocessorComparison
    comparison_type = greater_than_equals
    value_a = time
    value_b = 60
[]

If I change bool to value, I correctly get an error stating that the reporter has been requested of type std::vector<bool> but declared of type std::vector<double>. This indicates to me that my usage is fundamentally wrong. Based off the wording, I would think converged_reporter requires a bool, but I can't find any tests demonstrating usage of these keywords to guide me. Any help would be appreciated.
Also, as a side note, if  StochasticTools can print multiapp_converged in output .csv files, why can't skip_unconverged_samples simply be set to true without need for additional manipulation?
@zachmprince

Hi @higgnm, you seem to have found a very new capability in stochastic tools! Could you post your inputs to see exactly what you are trying to do?
To summarize how skip_unconverged_samples works. First, SamplerReporterTransfer automatically creates a reporter value of type std::vector<bool> which contains a value for each sample, true if the solve was able to converge and false if it doesn't. Whether the solve converged or not directly determined from the sub-app's nonlinear system, there is no need for a separate postprocessor or reporter to determine this. Second, these values are transferred to a StochasticReporter so the resulting name is <stochastic_reporter_name>/<transfer_name>:converged. Finally, the trainer has the option to skip samples where the solve did not converge by setting skip_unconverged_samples = true and converged_reporter = <stochastic_reporter_name>/<transfer_name>:converged.

That worked to get my cases running. Unfortunately I'm now getting a "Task add_vector_postprocessor is not registered to build Reporter derived objects" error which I believe relates to a new version of my program and is a separate issue. Your explanation of the reporter usage makes sense; I was mistaken on how to access the :converged value.

For which object are you getting this?
You need to move this object from the [VectorPostprocessor] block to the [Postprocessor] block I think
This error was arising from using a newer version (with the skip_unconverged_samples) without updating the surrogate evaluation syntax to the newer Reporter syntax.

node.title: Axissymmetric Problem with Peridynamics Module
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE Community
I wish to work with peridynamics module in order to simulate thermo-mechanical model for an axissymmetric problem regarding which I wish to know whether "FEProblem" declaration in Problems block will still work .....
Hoping to get headers in this direction.
Thanks
@hchen139

The MOOSE peridynamics module currently does not have axisymmetric models. Please refer to the test problems of the peridynamics module on how to write an input file to use available peridynamics capabilities in MOOSE.

Ohh, Thanks for clarifying this issue.....

node.title: Enforcing Jump Constraint in XFEM Module
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am trying to create a model for the evaporation of liquid into vapor, and am trying to use the XFEM and Level Set modules with the LevelSetCutUserObject for the interface. I am having difficulty directly enforcing the jump in heat across the moving boundary. In particular, I am trying to use the XFEMSingleVariableConstraint to enforce this jump condition but I'm not sure if this is the best way to go. Explicitly, the condition I am trying to implement is below:
We have simulated the following equations: Let $\phi$ be the signed distance function where for each time, $t$, the zero level set is the interface between liquid and vapor phases. Explicitly, the interface between the liquid and vapor phases is given by

Let the region with $\phi(x) > 0$ be the vapor phase and let the negative distances from the interface being identified with the liquid phase. Now, with this, we simulate the below two equations and reinforces energy jump condition across the interface:

Any ideas/help with how to would be greatly appreciated.
Thanks,
Pratyush

First, we have not really tried to combine XFEM and Level Set modules together yet. Issues there are: 1. what is the solution scheme to compute level set and physics model? Concurrently coupling or staggered coupling? 2. XFEM will cut the mesh, and you need some constraints to heal the mesh to run level set evolution equation.
Second, the set of equations does not seem to be complete. I think we still need a Dirichlet like BC to enforce the temperature jump. So far, you only have the flux BCs on the interface. For both interfacial conditions, you can use ElemElemConstraint to implement your weak forms.
Lastly, we have been developing a mesh-based moving interface capability. We use a mesh to represent the interface and we calculate the interface velocity on the cutting mesh to move the mesh. With that, you do not need to couple level set module. See #17813

node.title: L2 error for a transient simulation
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I'm following example 14 for calculating the L2 norm of the error for a transient wave propagation simulation. I'm using a fine mesh solution as my exact solution, however, I'm a bit confused with the multiple .xda and _mesh.xda files that are being generated for the fine mesh solution. I'm not sure which one to feed into the SolutionUserObject of the coarse mesh simulation. Is it going to be the last file (0200.xda and 0200_mesh.xda for a 200 timestep run)?
Thanks,
Leon

You can specify the highest number (so the latest timestep) or you can replace the number with .LATEST in your input file and it ll pick the latest.
Guillaume

node.title: Resolving Transient runtime Error: auto_advance=false
node.bodyText:
Hello,
In my SAM-MOOSE simulation, I'm getting this runtime error and don't know how to fix it.
FullSolveMultiApp is not compatible with auto_advance=false
I've tried making a SolveStep object and set auto_advance=true but it isn't recognized. I've also tried to manually change the bool value in other blocks but am still getting the error. Any advice on how to get rid of this error would help :)

Hello
Have you tried setting that parameter to false to the MultiApps block?
Is another moose app the subapp?
Guillaume

Hello
I've tried to manually change the parameter's bool value in the MultiApp block.
What do you mean by "another moose app being the subapp"? I know this subapp, (FullSolveMultiApp), runs a complete simulation every execution? That's the only app I define in the MultiApp block.
is the sub app SAM or is it a different app
Yes, I’m using SAM

Hi @GiudGiud, I'm part of the SAM developer team. Just wanted to check– the auto_advance = true parameter is set in the Executioner block, correct? This should be allowed, I don't believe SAM enforces any Executioner parameters. I'm not sure if anyone has previously worked with SAM on a FullSolveMultiApp problem, but it should be possible.
I just checked with one of our regression test TransientMultiApp problems and was able to run it as a FullSolveMultiApp by setting auto_advance = true in the Transient executioner block of the main app. It seems like it yielded the expected behavior, namely the sub app executing a full simulation for each tilmestep of the main app.

Hi Travis
Thanks for pitching in!
Good catch, it's an executioner parameter not a MultiApp parameter.
I was able to run a FullSolveMultiApp in my SAM inputs as well by setting this option.
SAM (or something) must be enforcing this parameter in some fashion. Other MOOSE apps do not require setting this parameter before using a FullSolveMultiApp.
Guillaume

node.title: Boundary conditions ignored by MOOSE
node.bodyText:
I created a simple mesh with gmsh for a simple flow under a dam. This is the content of the input file:
https://pastebin.com/tGFruT1s
Yet, when I run the simulation, the output seems to completely ignore the BCs, and I have flow_pot = 0 everywhere including at the boundaries I specified. I made my own custom kernels for this to try to learn how MOOSE works, by the way. And they compile fine:
Material Class: https://pastebin.com/pnUfeM3B
Kernel: https://pastebin.com/HBcT2KBq
.inp mesh file created:
https://pastebin.com/QrY55VzP

Hello
Gave a quick look and:

you dont need to specify zero Neumann BCs on the wall, that is a default
Is this just a diffusion problem? There are pre-built kernels for this btw
You dont seem to be initializing permeability in that source file. You only declare it. If it's a constant, you could use a GenericConstantMaterial. You could also have a look at that file to see how the prop_values are retrieved from the input file and placed in the properties at the quadrature points

Guillaume

Hi,
Yes it is, but I was trying to learn how to create the kernel using the material interface so I can apply it to a more complex problem.
I believe I fixed that now, and the simulation does seem to be calculating residuals now unlike before (where it would converge with one iteration and |r|=0). However, when I view the output with paraview, it's still giving me a value of flow_pot = 0 everywhere. I still used the 'ADMaterialProperty' btw, because the problem I eventually want to do isn't just a generic constant.
Here's the updated Material source file:
https://pastebin.com/stmsL7fK
So I set the _permeability at the quadrature points to always equal the constant value retrieved from the user (with _the_permeability).  The input file and kernel remain unchanged.

That's weird. Is paraview showing the initial condition by chance?
If there s a non zero residual, chances are the variable is not identically 0.

No, not even showing the boundary condition. The value of flow_pot ranges from 0 to 1e-38 (which I assume is computer precision for 0)
https://ibb.co/ZJDhQYW
However the residual calculation starts off large so its clearly calculating something:
0 Nonlinear |R| = 1.300704e+02
0 Linear |R| = 1.300704e+02
1 Linear |R| = 1.451357e-05
1 Nonlinear |R| = 1.031623e-05
0 Linear |R| = 1.031623e-05
1 Linear |R| = 1.702694e-12
2 Nonlinear |R| = 8.267341e-14
Solve Converged!

Ok I cant access the page, my chrome wont let me. Can you please post a paraview screenshot?
Alternatively, could you add postprocessors to characterize your solution? So like ElementAverageValue and SideAverageValue on the boundaries.
I would try to isolate the problem by replacing each part of your custom simulation with generic moose objects and see what improves it.

This is the paraview screenshot.
I added the postprocessors and its clearly calculating something, the SideAverageValue on each boundary returned the value of the boundary conditions. I also tried "SideAverageValue" for the walls, and that gave me a number in between both boundaries. So it means something is wrong with the .e output file.

Did you change anything about the output block?
In paraview, did you make sure to select the last timestep?

This is the output block:
[Outputs]
exodus = true
perf_graph = true
[]
And in paraview, for the last timestep (only two timesteps as expected for a Steady State calculation) the whole mesh = 1.2e-38
Edit: I've also been trying PointValue for random points within the mesh and they all return values between the BCs
Edit: I installed the latest version of paraview and finally got the solution displayed. A little bizarre imo but at least its working now. Thank you for your help!
ah great I was getting super confused. Thanks for letting us know. Good luck for the rest of the model!

Hi @GiudGiud
I see you mentioned

'You dont seem to be initializing permeability in that source file. You only declare it. If it's a constant, you could use a GenericConstantMaterial. You could also have a look at that file to see how the prop_values are retrieved from the input file and placed in the properties at the quadrature points'

I wonder if we can pre-define material properties such as permeability/porosity in the mesh file (.inp) and MOOSE will recognise it?
I want to specify a different value of the property at each element (base on element number/ID), is this possible with MOOSE?
Thank you.
Kind regards,
Traiwit

I'm not aware of this capability for .inp files.
Input of material properties is usually done per block.
You should post in another discussions thread to find out if there's a per-element option. I dont think there is, but maybe someone has done something similar before.

node.title: Issue with Neumann boundary conditions on .inp mesh created with gmsh
node.bodyText:
Hi, I have a mesh created with gmsh with a pretty simple geometry, but I'm having trouble using it with Neumann BCs.
https://easyupload.io/6p4kka
The above is the raw/unedited .inp export from gmsh- when I used this I got the error:
"Expected boundary element of dimension 2 but got 1"
So I manually deleted all the line and surface elements, and left only the volume element. I applied Dirichlet conditions on one of the "physical groups" I created, which is a surface of one side, and it ran fine.
The problem I'm facing now is applying Neumann condition to the same surface- I get:
*** ERROR ***
    the following side set ids do not exist on the mesh: 3

    MOOSE distinguishes between "node sets" and "side sets" depending on whether
    you are using "Nodal" or "Integrated" BCs respectively. Node sets corresponding
    to your side sets are constructed for you by default.

    Try setting "Mesh/construct_side_list_from_node_list=true" if you see this error.
    Note: If you are running with adaptivity you should prefer using side sets.

So I added that argument to the Mesh block, and nothing changed. I also thought it could be the element sets created by gmsh, and since I deleted all the surface elements, I should delete the surface elsets too (and leave only the nodesets). Doing that gave me the error:
*** ERROR ***
Invalid dimension dim = 4

I also tried remaking the mesh and instead of defining the surface as the boundary, I'd define the lines that make up the surface as the boundary (in the attached file, these are named "left_tract" and "right_tract"). I did that and tried in MOOSE but just got a segmentation fault with no backtrace.

Meaning the .geo file!
You can create sidesets with the SideSetsFromBoundingBoxGenerator, SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator, SideSetsFromNormalsGenerator, ParsedGenerateSideset etc. All those are MeshGenerators that would be chained after your FileMeshGenerator.
Hi Daniel, thanks for the tip! Also, I used the GUI to create the mesh, I guess I'll need to learn how to generate a mesh from a script so I can share that

I also tried giving MOOSE .msh files instead of .inp files, and I got this error:
Error: Exodus requires all elements with a given subdomain ID to be the same type.
Can't write both PYRAMID5 and TET4 in the same block!Error: Exodus requires all elements with a given subdomain ID to be the same type.
Can't write both PYRAMID5 and TET4 in the same block!

But in my mesh preferences, I selected:
2D Algorithm: MeshAdapt (I also tried "Automatic" and "Frontal Delaunay for Quads")
3D Algorithm: Delaunay (I tried all non "experimental" algorithms available).
2D Recombination Algorithm: Simple Full Quad
Subdivision Algorithm: All Quads
